M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody and parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment or order, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 (as applied to custody and visitation modifications) and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as well as the Court’s inherent and continuing jurisdiction over matters involving the custody, care, and best interests of minor children.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the prior order was issued by this Court and the minor child resides within Bristol County.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the prior order was issued by this Court and the minor child resides within Bristol County.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The “paramount concern” in all custody and parenting matters is the best interests and welfare of the child.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody and parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment or order, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general modification-of-custody standard case. It repeatedly frames the standard purely as whether removal is in the children’s best interests and, in the ALI quotation, notes relocation as a ‘substantial change,’ but it never sets out or applies the familiar two‑part Massachusetts test requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order and (2) that modification be in the child’s best interests. Thus it does not provide authority for the full proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’”

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 682–83 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody and parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment or order, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns child support arrearages and equitable credits under G.L. c. 119A, § 13(a), not the standards for modifying custody or parenting time. While the court briefly notes changed circumstances and best interests in passing when discussing child-related issues, it does not set out or apply the two-prong test for modifying custody or parenting time orders. Therefore, this case is not proper authority for the specific Massachusetts standard for modification of custody/parenting time orders.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.relevant_excerpt:
We discern no abuse of discretion with respect to the termination date of the father’s child support payments.

…

The mother further argues that the judge erred by ordering the mother to contribute to the children’s college expenses where the mother was excluded from the college selection process. We are unpersuaded. … As such, we discern no abuse of discretion in making the mother “responsible for her proportionate share of the college education costs of the children,” in lieu of paying child support to the father.

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.proposition: The “paramount concern” in all custody and parenting matters is the best interests and welfare of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters the governing and controlling principle is the welfare of the child, both as a matter of law and humanity, and that this consideration dominates over parental wishes. The court relies on and reaffirms prior precedents using language such as “dominating rule” and “controlling consideration,” which directly aligns with describing the child’s best interests and welfare as the “paramount concern” in custody and parenting matters.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.proposition: The “paramount concern” in all custody and parenting matters is the best interests and welfare of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the governing standard for custody determinations and cites prior Massachusetts authority stating that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern in such matters. The court reaffirms that custody awards must be determined by reference to the child’s best interests and welfare, expressly quoting earlier cases that use the term “paramount” for this principle. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that the best interests and welfare of the child are the paramount concern in custody and parenting matters.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 239\u201340.proposition: The Court may modify custody and parenting time orders when changed conditions affect the child’s welfare or safety, including changes concerning a parent’s stability, substance use, or ability to provide appropriate care during parenting time.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 239\u201340.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on child support in a shared physical custody context for never-married parents with high incomes. It does not address modification of custody or parenting time orders, nor does it discuss changed conditions related to a parent’s stability, substance use, or ability to provide appropriate care as grounds for altering custody or parenting time. The only discussion of changes in circumstances concerns child support recalculation on remand, not custody or parenting time modification, so it does not support the stated proposition.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 239\u201340.relevant_excerpt: "On remand, the judge is not required to revisit the issue of the father’s income at the time of trial, but should consider whether the circumstances have materially changed since the date of the judgment before us, and should base any award of child support on the parties’ current incomes."

Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215, 221–22 (2002)
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court may modify custody and parenting time orders when changed conditions affect the child’s welfare or safety, including changes concerning a parent’s stability, substance use, or ability to provide appropriate care during parenting time.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns valuation of a sole proprietorship, calculation of income, alleged double-dipping, and modification of alimony/support based on a change in the wife’s disability and finances. It does not address custody, parenting time, or changes related to a parent’s stability, substance use, or caregiving ability, nor does it set out standards for modifying custody or parenting orders. The only modification discussion is about financial support, not custody or parenting time, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In considering Joyce’s argument on appeal, we are mindful of our standard of review. As stated in Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26–27 (1981): ‘In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree.’ … Based upon the evidence, the findings, and the trial judge’s broad range of discretion, we must conclude that his decisions on the complaint for modification … are to stand.”

Care & Protection of Emily, 433 Mass. 35.proposition: When facts suggest impairment or risk to a child in a parent’s household, the Court has authority to adjust or condition parenting time, including imposing supervision or restrictions, to protect the child while preserving the parent‑child relationship when reasonably possible.
Care & Protection of Emily, 433 Mass. 35.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal homicide case dealing with sufficiency of the evidence, transferred intent, witness refusal to testify, self‑defense, ineffective assistance, and related issues. It does not involve child welfare, custody, parenting time, or any authority of a court to adjust or supervise a parent’s contact with a child. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition about conditioning parenting time to protect a child while preserving the parent‑child relationship.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: When facts suggest impairment or risk to a child in a parent’s household, the Court has authority to adjust or condition parenting time, including imposing supervision or restrictions, to protect the child while preserving the parent‑child relationship when reasonably possible.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on a child when determining custody, and on compliance with statutory requirements for written findings when shared custody is ordered in the face of a restraining order. It does not discuss, authorize, or frame any specific adjustment or conditioning of parenting time (such as supervision or restrictions) as a remedial tool to protect the child while preserving the parent‑child relationship. The remedy is a remand for additional findings, not an articulation of authority to impose supervised or restricted parenting time in light of risk within a parent’s household.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449, 453\u.proposition: When facts suggest impairment or risk to a child in a parent’s household, the Court has authority to adjust or condition parenting time, including imposing supervision or restrictions, to protect the child while preserving the parent‑child relationship when reasonably possible.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449, 453\u.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses relocation/removal standards and the Probate Court’s continuing authority to act in the child’s best interests notwithstanding a separation agreement. It does not deal with facts suggesting impairment or risk to a child in a parent’s household, nor does it discuss conditioning or supervising parenting time. The holding is about the applicable burden of proof and statutory standard for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not about imposing supervised or restricted parenting time to mitigate safety risks.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449, 453\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, and the standard of proof which it requires cannot be written off by the parties. The best interests of the child will control where there is a question as to whether the child will be removed from the Commonwealth. The jurisdiction of the Probate Court over the minor children of divorced parties may not be ousted by the terms of a separation agreement, and the court may, where the best interests of the child dictate, disregard the agreement.”
